> > Violating pre- and postconditions is just a small subset of what
> can go
> > wrong in your code. Unit tests often test the interplay of two or
> three
> > methods, or even of several objects. You can't do this 
> (effectively) 
> > with embedded assertions.
> 
> If you use Design by Contract then the implementation can be checked 
> by the compiler to be valid or not.

Are you sure? Can you show me an example of such a compiler message,
please?

> > Do you have a pointer?
> I don't know what you mean.

I meant something like a web-link. In the meantime I found the
JML-homepage, but the documentation is rather unorganized. Where does it
state that the checks are done at compile time?

> > That's wrong, as others already stated.
> 
> But how will you test a method which returns nothing?

By testing for the side effect.

Can you give an example of a method you think of as untestable by Junit?

> > Asserts are even less a guarantee. Asserts need to be 
> executed to be 
> > effective - if you don't have external code invoking them in a well 
> > directed manner, they will not be of any use until in the 
> production 
> > environment.
> 
> In my following posting I favor Design by Contract instead of just 
> using
> assert statements. I replied to myself. Read the thread when it 
> appears.

The same argument applies to DBC.

> > If you really prefer this way, it wouldn't be too hard to include
> the
> > unit tests into your production code. Most people seem to prefer to 
> > seperate the two.
> 
> I prefer Design by Contract. Most people don't know that paradigma.

Many TDDers do know.

> > Junit doesn't force you to develop test-driven at all.
> 
> It suggests it strongy I think. Otherwise the synchronisation of code 
> and test is endangered.

I don't follow you. All you need to do is run the tests regularly, so it
seems to me.

> > You might fear that it is. In practice, it doesn't seem to be that
> way.
> 
> If you use TDD in its intended form than you lose time. Thats my 
> opinion.

OK.

> > minutes. There are even tools to automate this. My IDE shows me 
> wether I
> > run the tests since the last code change, and an integration server
> > emails me if I broke a test nevertheless.
> 
> Still much work. I prefer to concentrate on code and not on test 
> quality.

For me, test quality has a huge impact on code quality. YMMV.

I also wonder what the big difference is between maintaining tests and
maintaining DBC-like contracts.

Regards, Ilja
